rename.from: helm repo add fails on mac
rename.to: helm repo add now fails in v3.3.2 and v3.3.3

issue.title: `helmfile repos` attempts to re-add already added repo
issue.body:
Hi, I just updated helmfile from `v0.128.0` to `v0.129.3` and strange behavior happens when I try to attempt repo-related actions. Am I missing something?

`helmfile` version: `0.129.3`
`helm` version: `3.3.2`

helmfile.yaml
```
repositories:
- name: stable
  url: https://kubernetes-charts.storage.googleapis.com

...
```

output:
```
$ helmfile repos                                                                                                       
Adding repo stable https://kubernetes-charts.storage.googleapis.com
in ./helmfile.yaml: command "/usr/local/bin/helm" exited with non-zero status:

PATH:
  /usr/local/bin/helm

ARGS:
  0: helm (4 bytes)
  1: repo (4 bytes)
  2: add (3 bytes)
  3: stable (6 bytes)
  4: https://kubernetes-charts.storage.googleapis.com (48 bytes)

ERROR:
  exit status 1

EXIT STATUS
  1

STDERR:
  Error: repository name (stable) already exists, please specify a different name

COMBINED OUTPUT:
  Error: repository name (stable) already exists, please specify a different name
```

body:
@darkn3rd 
```
You can add --force-update option when run helm repo add.
```

Hi, @darkn3rd - as explained in https://github.com/helm/helm/releases/tag/v3.3.2: 

> One breaking change was made: The default behavior of helm repo add was changed: It no longer overwrites repositories by default. The flag --force-update was added to helm repo add to allow a repo to be overwritten. The flag --no-update still exists, but does nothing. This change accords with the Helm policy for allowing minor breaking changes in the name of security.

@bridgetkromhout I saw that comment shortly after I wrote this.  This can be both secure and idempotent at the same time.  Both of these are not mutually exclusive.  Simply, if the repo exist, don't do anything, don't error when there is no error, as this breaks things.  

Upstream automation and tools, such as `helmfile`, now fail.

@yxxhero Thanks for the tip.  I can do that to return to the behavior, but then in `v3.3.1` and earlier, doing that will cause this:
```bash
$ helm repo add --force-update jaegertracing https://jaegertracing.github.io/helm-charts
Error: unknown flag: --force-update
```
This will break upstream automation and tools like `helmfile`, as now they'll have to test the version of helm and mutate the behavior.

Helm should just not do anything if the repo already exists, not create an error where no error.  If it was idempotent, it would also be secure in that manner, and the behavior as far as being in the desired state, would be similar.  The behavior would not break things.  The `--force-update` for other use cases, but for my use case, I just need the *not updating a repo* to not exit with an error, because there's no error.

Just wanted to add this behavior violates the principal of least surprise, as it diverges from the behavior inherent with countless other package managers that are idempotent in this aspect: chocolatey, homebrew, helm v.3.3.1 or earlier, apt-get, yum, emerge, ports, aur, pacman, etc.
Absolutely agree with @darkn3rd - it was even released as a bug-fix. We can do better!

Hmm... We could just return exit code zero if the same repo is attempted to be added twice with the same name. Since it isn’t changing the information that’s already there, that should resolve the issue without working around the security controls we had to put in place.

In other words, this should just exit zero as a no-op:

```
helm repo add jaegertracing https://jaegertracing.github.io/helm-charts
helm repo add jaegertracing https://jaegertracing.github.io/helm-charts
```

But this should still continue to return an error:

```
helm repo add jaegertracing https://jaegertracing.github.io/helm-charts
helm repo add jaegertracing https://someotherrepo.com/charts
```

What do you think about that?

@bacongobbler That would work.  

Also, for breaking changes in the future, it would be nice to have a heading, like `### Breaking Changes` in markdown.  Once I determine the version where this was introduced, I had to hunt for the information, combing through the text, until I spotted it.  If possible, it would also be good to have a major version bump for a breaking change, like `3.4`.  Breaking changes for a minor version causes a lot of problems.  I now have to document to customers not to use these versions as they break automation.

issue.title: change behavior when add repo with same name and url.

labels.name: size/L
labels.description: Denotes a PR that changes 100-499 lines, ignoring generated files.

issue.body:
Signed-off-by: yxxhero <aiopsclub@163.com>

<!--  Thanks for sending a pull request!  Here are some tips for you:
1. Make sure to read the Contributing Guide before submitting your PR: https://github.com/helm/helm/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
2. If this PR closes another issue, add 'closes #<issue number>' somewhere in the PR summary. GitHub will automatically close that issue when this PR gets merged. Alternatively, adding 'refs #<issue number>' will not close the issue, but help provide the reviewer more context.-->

**What this PR does / why we need it**:
resolve: https://github.com/helm/helm/issues/8771
We could just return exit code zero if the same repo is attempted to be added twice with the same name.

**Special notes for your reviewer**:

**If applicable**:
- [ ] this PR contains documentation
- [x] this PR contains unit tests
- [ ] this PR has been tested for backwards compatibility

issue.title: Fixing issue with idempotent repo add

labels.name: size/M
labels.description: Denotes a PR that changes 30-99 lines, ignoring generated files.

labels.name: needs-pick
labels.description: Indicates that a PR needs to be cherry-picked into the next release candidate.

labels.name: picked
labels.description: Indicates that a PR has been cherry-picked into the next release candidate.

issue.body:
A security issue fixed in 3.3.2 caught repos with the same name
being added a second time and produced an error. This caused an
issue for tools, such as helmfile, that will add the same name
with the same configuration multiple times.

This fix checks that the configuration on the existing and new
repo are the same. If there is no change it notes it and exists
with a 0 exit code. If there is a change the existing error is
returned (for reverse compat). If --force-update is given the
user opts in to changing the config for the name.

Closes #8771

- [ ] this PR contains documentation
- [x] this PR contains unit tests
- [x] this PR has been tested for backwards compatibility

body:
First, let me apologize for the lack of breaking change being bubbled up. It was noted on the pull request to fix the security issue (the only time we will intentionally make a breaking change is security issues) but we missed bubbling it up.

Second, I put up a PR to fix this issue at #8777. Can you please take a look and see if this will work.
I am tentatively marking this as a bug.

issue.title: return as no-op if repo name/url is identical

labels.name: size/S
labels.description: Denotes a PR that changes 10-29 lines, ignoring generated files.
